nodes.bodyText: Do we want to have an interface for it?
Currently, I don't see a need to introduce an interface only for the isEmpty() method.
Actually we added these things only for tests right? Do you see any possibility to do it differently without adding stuff to the production code?
Yes. The isEmtpy() methods are used in tests only. I think it's ok because it is simple and doesn't expose some internals of the class. I see no other ways to verify that the state is empty.

no should prefix anymore 👀 😱 what with our values and consistency 😄
I would suggest that we change it to something like shouldEndWithCleanStateOnWorkflowWithServiceTask
Can we have one test with input mapping? Does it make a difference?

Can we have one test with input mapping? Does it make a difference?

There is one test case with input and output mappings. It should cover the cases.

I would suggest that we change it to something like shouldEndWithCleanStateOnWorkflowWithServiceTask

Usually, I would agree. But in this case, all tests verify that the state is empty at the end - just with different parameters. It could be a ParameterizedTest but the workflow and steps are too different.
If we're using shouldEndWithCleanStateOnWorkflowWithServiceTask then the major part shouldEndWithCleanStateOnWorkflowWith is equal to all tests. So, I would like to shrink the name to what is different.
Do you agree with it?

What I normally then do is to name the Test as the common thing and as you meant use the difference as test method name, but still with should prefix.
For example AlwaysCleanStateTest #shouldBeTrueWithWorkflowServiceTask, #shouldBeTrueWithTimerEvent etc.
I did not find a better way for the naming. Also, a parameterized test doesn't work nicely here.
ok thanks for trying it
no given, when then comments anymore ?

Nope, but I have no strong option in this case 😅
For you, what is the value of this comments here?
It makes it more clear and is easier to read if you have the separators you can clearly see the sections. For me it is often that I can easier/faster understand the test.
Can we somehow just check whether the db is empty? I have the feeling this is a bit unstable if we miss to add a state here

+  @Test

+    final var workflowInstanceKey =

+    engineRule
+        .message()

+  @Test

+

+            .message()

+        .await();
+
+    engineRule.increaseTime(timeToLive.plus(MessageObserver.MESSAGE_TIME_TO_LIVE_CHECK_INTERVAL));
+
+    // deploy new workflow without message start event to close the open subscription
+    engineRule
+        .deployment()
+        .withXmlResource(Bpmn.createExecutableProcess(PROCESS_ID).startEvent().endEvent().done())
+        .deploy();
+
+    RecordingExporter.messageStartEventSubscriptionRecords(

nodes.bodyText:
Yes. The tests depend on the fact that all states are checked and isEmpty() is correct. I don't see how to enforce it.
At least for now, we can not check if the whole RocksDB is empty because the deployments are not removed.

+
+    final var timeToLive = Duration.ofSeconds(10);

+        engineRule
+            .message()
+            .withName("message")
+            .withCorrelationKey("key-1")
+            .withTimeToLive(timeToLive)
+            .withVariables(Map.of("x", 1))
+            .publish();
+
+    final var workflowInstanceKey =
+        RecordingExporter.workflowInstanceRecords(WorkflowInstanceIntent.ELEMENT_ACTIVATING)

+    // deploy new workflow without message start event to close the open subscription
+    engineRule
